title: Planning 2 invest in restaurant. Is there an investment contract template I can look at as a guide to cover the legal aspects
question: I will have a 51% interest and will control and manage all the financial aspects of the business. Should I set up a separate management company for that aspect or no?
answers: there are alot of things to consider. You should consult with and have a small business attorney near you draft an agreement.

Your question indicates you have never done this before. 2nd question first, no you don't need a second company. First question - are you buying into an existing restaurant. Do you have a CPA and/or lawyer to do "due diligence" and what debts may be outstanding, the status of the taxes, leases, etc. A template won't be enough. If you will be in west Los Angeles ... doland@dolandlaw.com

If you are going to be a 51% investor, you are really the "owner". You should retain an attorney to handle this for you as setting up, running, and operating a restaurant is complex. I have set up the business, business plan, etc for restaurants in the East Bay. The ones with investors were the most difficult because even the smallest investor wanted to call the shots. Also, if you are 51% investors, you are the one the taxing authorities are going to pursue, individually, if the restaurant fails. I hope yours is successful, but the restaurant business is tricky so its best to be prepared.

Search “restaurant business” and “restaurant business plan” on Google. Lots of info. You really should consult a business lawyer.
A separate management company (LLC or S Corp) might be a good idea if you are concerned that your fellow investors might sue you.
